card: SummaryCard(title='The digital pound: A new form of money for households and businesses?', url='https://b-o-e.uk/3RCIQbf', description='Consultation Paper', thumbnailUrl='https://pbs.twimg.com/card_img/1624028562222379008/hx5dRe7s?format=png&name=orig', siteUser=None, creatorUser=None)

tweet_text: Digital pounds would be stored directly at the Bank of England, but users would access these through digital wallets offered by private companies. Find out more here: https://t.co/5SydfXouQp https://t.co/p72HmR1AGx

The Bank of England would not be able to restrict how users’ digital pounds are spent. But innovations in technology may allow users to program their money to use it in new ways. Find out more here: https://t.co/PkuiMmjR12 https://t.co/lhdXr0CpaK
Our consultation paper proposes a range of features for the digital pound that meet our objectives. Find out more about these here: https://t.co/FXXmPZ0cT6 https://t.co/HwjbOdjLxl
The digital pound would be designed for everyday payments by households and businesses. Find out more about the other features here: https://t.co/sV0Bo2ZqUu https://t.co/saZM4eQ0Dc

The digital pound would be subject to rigorous standards of privacy and data protection. It would be privacy-enhancing by design and would allow users to make choices about their data. Find out more here: https://t.co/3Xg5Z0VCiN https://t.co/nQrHGloaWN

Today the Bank of England and @hmtreasury have published a Consultation Paper on the digital pound, a UK central bank digital currency. Find out more here: https://t.co/jISyz0kvtb https://t.co/KhYOY0Dlaz

tweet_text: We’ve raised #BankRate to 4% today. Inflation has started to fall, but it is still much too high. Raising interest rates is the best way we have to ensure low and stable inflation. Andrew Bailey explains more below. https://t.co/n7j94kLoaX https://t.co/QRLtzXchxi

We’ve put up interest rates to make sure inflation falls and stays low. Raising interest rates is the best way we have to bring inflation down. https://t.co/n7j94kKQlp #MonetaryPolicyReport https://t.co/c426VMTnP5

We expect inflation to fall quickly this year. It’s our job to make sure that inflation returns to our 2% target. Low and stable inflation is vital for a healthy economy. https://t.co/n7j94kKQlp #MonetaryPolicyReport https://t.co/9XfXUvEpVc
Inflation has begun to fall, but it’s still well above our 2% target. https://t.co/n7j94kKQlp #MonetaryPolicyReport https://t.co/1RbfGuNPBP
The Monetary Policy Committee voted by a majority of 7-2 to raise #BankRate to 4%. Find out more in our #MonetaryPolicyReport: https://t.co/n7j94kKQlp https://t.co/wudQD5gZy5

tweet_text: Rapid and large moves in the interest rates on UK government debt (gilts) caused stress in a particular non-bank sector (LDI funds). tweet_text: We expect inflation will be close to our 2% target in around two years. It’s our job to make sure that inflation returns to our 2% target, and that is what we will do. https://t.co/389XbdQZWf #MonetaryPolicyReport #Inflation https://t.co/BVJc28AxuT

We’ve put up interest rates to help return inflation to our 2% target. What happens to interest rates in the coming months will depend on what happens in the economy. https://t.co/389XbdQZWf #MonetaryPolicyReport https://t.co/6enYvRHKOI

We know the cost of living squeeze is difficult for many people. The squeeze on households’ incomes due to the rise in energy prices has led to slower growth in the UK economy. We expect the size of the UK economy to fall over the coming year. https://t.co/389XbdQZWf https://t.co/71er2SAVqH
Inflation is over 9%. We expect it to rise further this year to around 13%, due to higher energy bills. https://t.co/389XbdQZWf #MonetaryPolicyReport #Inflation https://t.co/KNTgqqEU7Z
The Monetary Policy Committee voted by a majority of 8-1 to increase #BankRate to 1.75%. Find out more in our #MonetaryPolicyReport: https://t.co/389XbdQZWf https://t.co/OcqtaWjFuX
As part of our partnership with the Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office, we are pleased to co-direct this regional African central bank workshop with @thebankofghana. @FCDOGovUK

tweet_text: UK banks remain strong and are able to support households and businesses. https://t.co/HrpZV9ufUm #FinancialStabilityReport https://t.co/B4LmlbopXx

Markets for commodities – such as oil and gas – play a vital role in the economy. The Russian invasion of Ukraine and worsening economic outlook have caused markets to be volatile in recent months. This has increased costs for businesses and households. https://t.co/HrpZV9ufUm https://t.co/QOLUeCDcPb

Businesses are also under pressure from higher interest rates and the rise in prices. We expect the number of highly-indebted businesses to increase in the year ahead, particularly in more vulnerable sectors. https://t.co/HrpZV9ufUm #FinancialStabilityReport https://t.co/JdoEZhiV70

Household finances are under pressure from higher interest rates and the rise in prices. We expect household finances to become more stretched in the year ahead. https://t.co/HrpZV9ufUm #FinancialStabilityReport https://t.co/i7cvGHSogT
Our latest Financial Stability Report sets out what we are doing to make sure the UK’s financial system stays strong. https://t.co/HrpZV9ufUm #FinancialStabilityReport https://t.co/4M8Lb2IHhQ

tweet_text: We recently tested the UK’s largest banks and insurers on how prepared they are for financial risks caused by climate change. Sam Woods talks about the results. https://t.co/SEsMqyi8tm https://t.co/VOqi7qViB1

Banks and insurers have a collective interest in supporting the transition to a net zero emissions economy over time. Some improvements to their climate risk management will need to be made in order to do so. Find out more: https://t.co/cQm74MqJZq

We found that UK banks and insurers are likely to be able to bear the costs of transition to net zero greenhouse gas emissions that fall on them. The overall costs are likely to be lowest with early, well-managed action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. https://t.co/yhA1tnyZW8 https://t.co/7TQcj1BbpE

We asked UK banks and insurers to use three scenarios to look at how climate-related risks could affect them. Two scenarios feature policies to limit global temperature rises, the third features no additional action to limit global warming. https://t.co/cJd9CnmOuh https://t.co/azmG1vPJnm

Climate change and potential responses to it can impact businesses, households, and the financial system. We have run an exercise to explore the effects of climate-related risks on UK banks and insurers. The results are out today: https://t.co/5WVYI19sKG https://t.co/k0ARwOe3MR

tweet_text: @Walter_Essex Hi, inflation which is low and stable provides the best economic conditions. If it is too high, it is hard for businesses to set the right prices and if we have deflation(falling prices) people may delay spending. This can cause deep recessions. tweet_text: We have increased interest rates to support inflation returning to our 2% target. Making sure inflation returns to target will support people’s jobs and incomes. https://t.co/UT5RX7qzHv #MonetaryPolicyReport https://t.co/EL9v55wiaW
The UK economy continues to recover. We expect the UK economy to grow over the next few years. https://t.co/UT5RX7qzHv #MonetaryPolicyReport https://t.co/yTDtjSdgJf

Inflation is above our 2% target. We expect it to rise to around 7% in the spring, but then fall back and be close to our 2% target in around two years’ time. https://t.co/UT5RX7qzHv #MonetaryPolicyReport #Inflation https://t.co/xa3p5sDdSs

The Monetary Policy Committee voted by a majority of 5-4 to increase #BankRate to 0.5% and voted unanimously to begin to reduce the amount of quantitative easing. Find out more in our #MonetaryPolicyReport: https://t.co/UT5RX7qzHv https://t.co/l5N4OIno5v

We welcomed our new @BoEYouthForum members last month. They have been meeting some of the Bank’s senior team, including Andrew Bailey, to learn about our role in the economy.

Find out more about the Bank of England Youth Forum:
https://t.co/WOiMJxs82V

We are keeping interest rates low. We will continue to set interest rates to support UK households and businesses and ensure inflation returns to our 2% target.

These risks and consequences matter for our mission to maintain monetary and financial stability.', thumbnailUrl='https://pbs.twimg.com/card_img/1624479807172902913/rKO7cT_g?format=jpg&name=orig', siteUser=None, creatorUser=None)

tweet_text:
Our climate scenarios help us to understand the risks UK banks and insurers may face from a hotter world. 

In our scenario where no additional action is taken, global warming reaches 3.3 °C.

We look at how global warming could affect the weather in the UK. 

Using @metoffice data we found it will get much wetter in winter if nothing is done to reduce global warming. This means a greater risk of flooding, which would affect banks and insurers’ customers. https://t.co/Q6qSAl3vtH

tweet_text:
We are keeping interest rates low. This action will support households and businesses by keeping the cost of borrowing down.
https://t.co/QWJDoHlg4v #MonetaryPolicyReport https://t.co/Iz79tRDsyt

Inflation is still low, largely due to the effects of Covid. Inflation should return to around our 2% target later this year, as these effects fade. 
https://t.co/QWJDoHlg4v #MonetaryPolicyReport https://t.co/DQklwppOPR

We expect spending in the UK to rise sharply, as more people are vaccinated and restrictions to control the spread of Covid are lifted.
https://t.co/QWJDoHlg4v #MonetaryPolicyReport https://t.co/NchQvAwwrI

We examine the impact of Covid on the economy in our latest #MonetaryPolicyReport.
https://t.co/QWJDoHlg4v https://t.co/yErmvSwt97

The Monetary Policy Committee voted unanimously to keep interest rates at 0.1% and by a majority of 8-1 to maintain the amount of quantitative easing at £895bn.
https://t.co/QWJDoHlg4v #MonetaryPolicyReport #BankRate https://t.co/9LenVPxvpe

tweet_text: @AMSOilTrader Hello, you can find Andrew Bailey's opening remarks on our website: https://t.co/R6QgekkNfD

We are keeping interest rates low. This action will support households and businesses by keeping the cost of borrowing down.
https://t.co/lQh60YO9J2 #MonetaryPolicyReport https://t.co/sBGzZ1I2tE

Inflation is still low. The prices of the things we typically buy went up by 0.6% during 2020. That is less than our 2% target.
https://t.co/lQh60YO9J2 #MonetaryPolicyReport https://t.co/AggqAhRWxG

Spending in the UK has fallen. Vaccines should help the UK economy recover rapidly later this year.

https://t.co/iT1Jnkv8Zy https://t.co/oVPcGhutXU

Andy Haldane explains how our independence to set policy can offer a twin-win. It plays a key role in how we control inflation and keep banks safe. https://t.co/RTn9EhXa6H https://t.co/01QUUJB9AC

We have partnered with @WarwickBSchool to offer the Global Central Banking & Financial Regulation Qualification. tweet_text: Cash payments fell during Covid, due in part to concerns about banknotes transmitting the virus. Our research shows the risk of transmission via banknotes is low, so you can continue to use cash with confidence. Find out more: https://t.co/vrzPmUqdeI https://t.co/sHaJ00R8vC

People are using cash less often to pay for things. During Covid cash payments have declined further, but the demand for banknotes has continued to increase. Why? To learn more about the banknote paradox, read our latest article: https://t.co/7VaeS167Y8 #Covid19 https://t.co/IR7aIEQw7M

Northern Ireland – we’re listening. On 15 December we will host our next virtual #BoECitizensPanel for residents in Northern Ireland. We want to find out how the economic situation is affecting you. 

Sign up to take part here: https://t.co/KiMHLTMnMg https://t.co/3zbw0zfuWf

Last chance to sign up for our virtual Citizens’ Panel for residents in North East England, taking place on 1 December. 

Register before 23 November to take part and help us understand how the economic situation is affecting you: https://t.co/gAWOMVqavm #BoECitizensPanel https://t.co/zFPgS3d127

Developments in digital finance could transform how consumers and businesses make payments and raise finance. This could help revitalise the UK economy, says Andy Haldane. https://t.co/0mrnkdvJ4Z https://t.co/NORbR6TanV

Dave Ramsden looks at the impact of the Covid pandemic on the UK economy. He examines what the long-term effects are and how the economy is likely to respond. https://t.co/hJy7khIsIi #Covid19 https://t.co/OYLcILRH73

Anil Kashyap looks at what happened in the financial markets during March of this year. 

He examines how different parts of the financial system, and the funding flows between them, can contribute to problems in times of stress. 
https://t.co/Uj5nQGrl7S https://t.co/qnjWem4spa

Andrew Bailey talks about the long-term effects of Covid and the investment required to support the recovery. 

Ensuring the supply of finance for productive investment will be important for long-term growth and for financial stability, he says. https://t.co/2NmsMWkPLr #Covid19 https://t.co/yXgfTD5ny6

Last year, we published the Resolvability Assessment Framework (RAF). It is designed to help banks manage the challenges they might face in a crisis scenario and subsequent resolution. Read our latest article to find out more: https://t.co/Q3eWESEzEh https://t.co/fJIk7RlbTt

We have lit up our Threadneedle Street building in blue, pink and white in support of Transgender Awareness Week. We want to raise the visibility of and celebrate transgender people everywhere. #TransAwarenessWeek2020 https://t.co/xlScAaa1MY
We’ve worked with the @Econ_Foundation to develop a free education resource for students exploring the future of work. Find out more and download here: https://t.co/3kobOqI9V5 https://t.co/fn0Npn2qKt

tweet_text: Profound changes in the financial and economic system call for research outside traditional central banking topics. The Transformed World theme investigates fundamental risks such as pandemics, the “new economy”, automation and business dynamism. https://t.co/Q3ZpyVfbH9

New developments in finance have the potential to remodel the financial system. The Future of Finance theme examines the effects of technological innovation, suptech, digital currencies and the consequences for systemic efficiency. https://t.co/J9zvzys8gG

Prudential policy has evolved substantially and is now a key policy responsibility in its own right. This theme deepens knowledge on macroprudential models, non-banks and policy interactions. https://t.co/cG3jSWjFdT

International economic and financial linkages are being re-shaped. The Open Economy theme explores issues around trading networks, the international monetary system, exchange rates and capital flows. https://t.co/ymtQS2iBXA

The key issues for monetary policymakers have changed significantly over time. The Monetary Toolkit theme looks at questions around new policy instruments, the effective lower bound, central bank communication and heterogeneity. https://t.co/sfBdnHo4z2

Research is crucial to what any central bank does. Today we are proud to launch our new Bank of England Agenda for Research. This sets out five key areas for new research over the coming years. 

https://t.co/v2kZO8HDKj https://t.co/5w8Nxa5nnC
Read the latest #PRARegulatoryDigest for a round-up of news and publications: https://t.co/iCZ7c4sraO

tweet_text:
@jiffers Hi Geoff 

Paper and polymer notes cost a few pence to make.  Polymer is more expensive but lasts much longer and is more resilient to counterfeiting.  Our aim is to produce high quality banknotes that the public can trust and polymer is the best way of delivering on this duty.

tweet_text:
The mortgage measures we introduced in 2014 guard against the damage to the economy that would be caused if lending standards went from responsible to reckless, as they have in the past.
https://t.co/EBsH9mPjby  #FinancialStabilityReport https://t.co/k3Cu6ZP8jx

UK banks will have more flexibility to use their capital to absorb losses. So they’ll have even more room to keep lending to UK households and businesses in recessions.
https://t.co/EBsH9mPjby  #FinancialStabilityReport https://t.co/tmvgaDBx0P

Whatever system you use to make payments, old or new, your money will need to be protected to the same standards.
https://t.co/EBsH9mPjby  #FinancialStabilityReport https://t.co/YSH4oJ5qtA

Our 2019 stress test shows that major UK banks are strong enough to carry on lending to households and businesses even in a recession worse than the financial crisis.
https://t.co/EBsH9mPjby  #FinancialStabilityReport https://t.co/odZdgNKEJg

Our latest #FinancialStabilityReport shows how we are making the financial system resilient to, and prepared for, the wide range of risks it could face.  
https://t.co/EBsH9mPjby https://t.co/9pCnS21SPp

tweet_text: @6_tibbz Hi, Fiat money is government-issued currency that is not backed by a physical commodity, such as gold or silver, but rather by the government that issued it.  At various times, GBP was commodity money or bank notes backed by silver or gold, but it is currently fiat money,

@jamestoon09 Anyone in the UK can refuse acceptance of a banknote in payment for goods or services, without necessarily giving a reason for doing so. Some banks and businesses in England will refuse Scottish notes, whilst others will accept them (3/3)

tweet_text: @jamestoon09 Whilst Scottish and Northern Ireland notes circulate freely around the UK, neither are actually ‘legal tender’ anywhere in the UK. Current Bank of England notes are 'legal tender' in England and Wales, but not in either Scotland or Northern Ireland (2/3)

tweet_text: @jamestoon09 Hi James, thanks for your message. The term ‘legal tender’ has little practical application. People are often willing to accept payment by cheque, standing order, debit or credit card for example – but none of these are actually ‘legal tender’ (1/3)

Thank you for your enquiry. 

As the central bank for the UK, we only have responsibility for UK banknotes. However, the Central Bank of Ireland can deal with damaged Euros for the UK.
Further information can be found here: https://t.co/nsUqn0EIDy

Kind Regards
Molly

tweet_text: Michael Saunders argues that, despite the recent drop in CPI inflation, the output gap is probably closed. He then goes onto discuss why, in his view, the economy will move further into excess demand than the MPC currently forecasts. https://t.co/T54m0RqwfV https://t.co/mtNlgIwXPE

tweet_text: Pay rises for most people have been low in recent years. But pay is now rising at a faster rate. This helps the economy to grow. https://t.co/JeCnuRnHqd #InflationReport https://t.co/VNK3njnFqS
Prices are rising at slower pace. We expect them to be below our 2% target later this year due to cheaper gas prices for households. https://t.co/JeCnuRnHqd #InflationReport https://t.co/94dyNNlrqw
Overall, businesses have continued to hire people despite investing less. https://t.co/JeCnuRnHqd #InflationReport https://t.co/vXPwvBeMU7
UK business investment has fallen over the past year. We think this is mainly because of uncertainty over Brexit https://t.co/JeCnuRnHqd #InflationReport https://t.co/ebHH0QUvTK
Interest rates are still much lower than before the financial crisis. https://t.co/JeCnuRnHqd #InflationReport https://t.co/FRdfwAQKFu
We have kept interest rates at 0.75%. Find out why in our visual summary: https://t.co/NErJey2wDI #InflationReport https://t.co/e66OrM3Owm
Monetary policy summary and minutes of the MPC meeting ending on 01 May 2019: https://t.co/QoqZvTztKl https://t.co/SrdgoxFHgB
MPC voted unanimously to keep #BankRate at 0.75% https://t.co/ldPGXMJ9hk

tweet_text: This year, we’re once again subjecting banks to a stress test tougher than the global financial crisis. https://t.co/49j1OZ133Z #FPCstatement https://t.co/sWxVom9WXn

In the global economy, debt vulnerabilities remain material in China and some emerging markets, the US corporate sector and Italy. These vulnerabilities are captured in our stress test of major banks. https://t.co/49j1OZ133Z  #FPCstatement https://t.co/E0jWc4SuZe

Major UK banks have access to enough liquidity to withstand a major disruption in financial markets. This will help banks to serve the economy even if markets are disrupted. https://t.co/49j1OZ133Z #FPCstatement https://t.co/TbPh1XUCmj
The core banking system is strong enough to withstand even the economic shocks that would accompany a worst case disorderly Brexit. https://t.co/49j1OZ133Z   #FPCstatement https://t.co/LYBcPsABde

Most risks to UK financial stability from disruption in a no-deal Brexit have been mitigated. But there will be disruption for people in the EU which could also affect people in the UK. https://t.co/49j1OZ133Z  #FPCstatement https://t.co/kLWL0bsH24
Our latest Financial Policy Summary shows how we’re making the financial system prepared for, and resilient to, a disorderly Brexit. https://t.co/sICpn2eqOS #FPCstatement https://t.co/4EuWNCprq4

Investment by businesses has fallen over the past year. They say it’s mainly because of uncertainty about Brexit. https://t.co/AM3JoznhwV #InflationReport https://t.co/h8n6EoK2rW

tweet_text: The Financial Policy Committee is monitoring how the access of households and businesses in the UK and EU to financial services could be disrupted as a result of Brexit. https://t.co/kxazrIzFZW #FinancialStabilityReport https://t.co/Ijd4BpFswD
The impact on UK banks from a disorderly Brexit scenario is smaller than our in 2018 stress test scenario. https://t.co/kxazrIzFZW #FinancialStabilityReport https://t.co/8l3Z5MPeiW
The 2018 stress test scenario is more severe than the financial crisis, but UK banks could continue to lend https://t.co/kxazrIzFZW #FinancialStabilityReport https://t.co/MpJKMHRNuJ

Our 2018 stress test shows that UK banks could continue to lend, even in deep simultaneous UK and world recessions worse than the financial crisis, combined with large falls in asset prices and a stress of misconduct costs. https://t.co/kxazrIzFZW #FinancialStabilityReport https://t.co/9s9GscKgzr

There are a range of possible scenarios. Reflecting their different roles, the FPC focus on worst-case outcomes with implications for financial stability, while the MPC considers the progress and impact of negotiations around the new Economic Partnership. https://t.co/4GaqqrCGdv https://t.co/Iju377uMaT
Today as requested by the House of Commons Treasury Committee the Bank of England has published analysis as to how Brexit may affect our ability to deliver our objectives. https://t.co/4GaqqrCGdv

Monetary policy summary and minutes of the MPC meeting ending on 31 October 2018: https://t.co/0HkRIeljCD https://t.co/biPV0PZfHN

tweet_text: Confused about prudential regulation? Demystify with our #BoEKnowledgeBank guide on the Prudential Regulation Authority. https://t.co/AvhdQgk957 https://t.co/gLJSZ8h8kc

We’ve created rainbow lanyards to show support for our LGBT+ colleagues. Because everyone should be able to be their true selves at work. And we want our workforce to reflect the public we serve. #LGBT and #allies #NationalComingOutDay https://t.co/jFFAu6hPGJ
In his speech, our Chief Economist Andy Haldane discusses the key factors driving the ‘lost decade’ of pay growth since the financial crisis. https://t.co/LcuGrXat11 https://t.co/qgJjzgQMz3
There has been a rise in emerging market debt in the past decade.  It makes those economies, and the world economy, riskier. https://t.co/qVKoIAK1mM #FPCstatement https://t.co/E7dQJ7CcVZ

The Financial Policy Committee is concerned by the rapid growth of high-risk leveraged lending, including to UK businesses. It will assess any implications for banks in the 2018 stress test. https://t.co/qVKoIAK1mM #FPCstatement https://t.co/tUbhjj7f2U

Levels of UK household and corporate debt relative to incomes remain materially below their 2008 levels, though they remain high by international and historical standards. Debt servicing burdens remain low. https://t.co/qVKoIAK1mM #FPCstatement https://t.co/PdmnSIzMpL

Unless EU rules change, the contracts that EU clearing members have with UK clearing houses will need to be closed out, or transferred, before March 2019. https://t.co/qVKoIAK1mM #FPCstatement https://t.co/13COn36RLW

The FPC is monitoring where households and businesses in the UK and EU could see their access to financial services disrupted if sudden barriers to trade go up. https://t.co/qVKoIAK1mM #FPCstatement https://t.co/LGqZtoHnjr

The FPC continues to judge that the UK banking system would be strong enough to serve UK households and businesses through a disorderly, cliff-edge Brexit. https://t.co/qVKoIAK1mM #FPCstatement https://t.co/JuPA74LssJ

tweet_text: Firms need to transition away from using Libor. There may be too few transactions to set Libor reliably after 2021. If the outstanding stock of contracts maturing after 2021 that reference Libor continues to increase, so will associated medium-term financial stability risks. https://t.co/dXYyYSU91q

Firms will have to show they can restore services quickly after cyber-attacks.  Firms will be subject to cyber stress tests and will need to prove they can recover quickly, or agree remedial plans with us. https://t.co/BxCZY2OgmT

There’s been progress to avoid disruption to financial services during Brexit, but more needs to be done. The UK will legislate if necessary to avoid disruption. A technical working group has been established, chaired by the European Central Bank and the Bank of England. https://t.co/xCABnqU0Ah

Global risks are material, and have increased.  Risks are rising in some emerging markets. Debt levels in China remain highly elevated.  And recent events in Italy suggest rising risks in the euro area. https://t.co/lVJ8rHT4An

Risk appetite in the UK has fallen in recent months, but remains strong. And while lending to riskier firms has increased, much of this has happened outside of the banking system – meaning banks are less exposed to these risks. https://t.co/u4UqPhCWTS
Domestic risks – apart from those related to Brexit – are standard overall. Debt has increased only a little faster than the economy over the past couple of years. https://t.co/9KUxTFz9WF

UK banks are strong enough to serve households and businesses in bad times as well as good. Our 2017 stress test showed that UK banks could withstand a deep recession – including a disorderly Brexit. https://t.co/BdV5daRIE4
We’re making the financial system resilient to risks and prepared to avoid future disruption. https://t.co/5EQUyJGpFw

tweet_text: 5.  In a world of divisions and opportunities, fusion will bring breakthroughs. Recognise that while diversity is a reality, inclusion is a choice. Take it.
4. Combine personal humility, self-knowledge and the ability to learn.
3. Be clear. This starts with clarity of mind and sound judgement. And extends to the ability to reduce complex problems to essentials and communicate them using narratives.
2. Be ambitious for your organisation, define your purpose & stick to it obsessively.  Purpose must be grounded in the objectives of clients, society and humanity.
1. Leaders must find & develop the right people, set the priorities for their organisation & catalyse action.

tweet_text: With record numbers in work, future growth will need to come from higher productivity – our ability to produce more with the people and resources we have. Find out more:  https://t.co/UZqN2AXnTw #InflationReport https://t.co/BHcwohEgny
Mark Carney at the #InflationReport press conference. Watch live: https://t.co/L8shnbvO81 https://t.co/nPIcqV5mDo
